  59. I have a Philips Norelco 7310XL electric shaver. I have had it over two years and finally the cutters stopped cutting. I noticed that these replacement blades were half the price of an entire new shaver. However, my shaver is still running well on battery so I figured I would buy these replacements and save myself some money.<br />I am glad I did. The shaver runs great with these replacement blades and cuts much better. As a matter of fact, before the blades completely quit it would pull my hair a little. Now it cuts without pulling any hairs. I also don't have to make as many passes to get the same results, saving me time.<br />Some of the reviews I read mentioned that these blades did not fit in their 7310XL. I believe that person either was sent the wrong blades by mistake or did not realize that these blades fit in a little differently. They are shaped slightly different so you can only put them in one way and not just drop them in any direction. In my opinion this is an improvement to the design because now the blade covers will not have any chance of spinning with the blades.
  60. You're doing a great job! Keep up the good work!

I apply \\"William's Lectric Shave\\" before and \\"Nivea Post Shave Balm\\" after shaving; the alcohol based after shave I was using caused redness and burning around my neck.   190. These are fine new cutting heads. However, I have in the past used a Vollco sharpener, which I just found in the drawer from my previous Norelco! Amazon also carries these (search Vollco Sharpening Heads For Select Norelco Models)and they are great, work like a charm to make your 'old' heads last 3-4x longer as long as you take care of them. I would suggest getting both a set of new heads and a sharpener set so that you can 1) sharpen your old heads to like new condition and then 2) have the backup of the new set for when you need them. My experience is that the re-sharpened heads dull just a bit faster than new originals and you really can only get a few sharpenings from them before they need replacing.

  334. I am only one week into my new shaving experience and so far I am greatly impressed. I was very skeptical about making the jump to electric razing, having used traditional razors my entire life. The worst part of the experience has always been shaving my neck: Occasionally I get ingrown hairs or various degrees of skin irritation. I tried every brand of razor and had the same experiences, overall. I found it cost (in the long run) quite a bit and the smooth surface didn't last long at all. If I went against the grain, naturally it would last longer, but would promote more irritation. Amazon offered a coupon for this item and I figured I had nothing to lose. The great bulk of reviews were on the high side and I figured why not?<br /> How was my experience? I kept an open mind and read the directions thoroughly. Norelco offered a window of time to not only adjust to the product but also offer a refund if not fully satisfied. Immediately I noticed a brilliant difference that rivaled the experience of the razor experience. Hair comes off MUCH easier and the surface is much smoother (for much longer!) Plus, the best part is much less irritation. I will not lie, however, my first time there was some irritation still on my neck area. Hair on my cheeks and upper lip come off with such great ease. Having read feedback and instructions, I am still working on my neck. I know there is an adjustment period and I'm hoping it will become much easier (in time!) I've already noticed a great difference in the past couple days and hope it will be a great experience for my entire face! I will update this feedback, after a couple of months to see if there is truly a difference.<br /> My advice? Give this razor a shot, you have nothing to lose! It's cheap and comes form a trustworthy brand. The best part is they offer your money back, if not satisfied! Hope this feedback helps!

  371. So I replaced the heads...not really too difficult...and my shaver was working like new again. When I took out the old ones I noticed they were pretty gunked up so I wondered how they would do cleaned up. Took them apart, cleaned with a brush, and reinstalled and they also worked ALMOST AS WELL as the replacement ones. Downloaded and read the manual (what, did you think I actually kept...or read the one that came with it?) and saw that I should have been cleaning these heads once a month by removing, disassembling and running under hot water. I had been simply opening the top and cleaning that cavity with a brush once a week or so and didn't consider taking the whole thing apart. Well, at least I have a set ready when these originals actually do need replacing. If there are other dummies out there like me, try this before ordering the replacement heads.

  428. About a year after I got my new Philips electric razor as a present I noticed it wasn't shaving as close as it used to. Duh! The blades don't stay sharp forever, dummy! I decided to go with the brand-name replacements, mainly because I trust the name - and I couldn't find any cheaper, generic versions anywhere. They probably exist, but I didn't find them. These factory replacements fit perfectly and it really only takes about a minute to make the switch. They will only go in one way, so it's hard to make a mistake. Yeah, it would be nice if you could sharpen the existing blades, but that's probably not very practical. Anyway, after the swap my razor was back working like new - and I even made a note to myself when I put in the new blades so I'll know when it's time to do it again.
  429. These blades last a good year or two. A good buy.

  431. This is a great price for these replacement heads. And, a few weeks after I purchased a set, my wife was shopping Amazon on Black Friday and picked up a another set for me at an even lower price ($16.88), with an on-line $5 off from Philips that Amazon automatically provided at checkout. These replacement heads are made by Philips, for their Spectra line of razors, and are not aftermarket. They correctly fit my Norelco Spectra model 8895XL electric razor (side note: my model is the &#34;James Bond special edition&#34; with a &#34;Die Another Day/007&#34; logo on it, that I purchased in 2002). Not sure how long Philips is going to make replacement parts like this for a 14 year old razor. [One slight difference from sets i purchased a few years ago. The original ones were stamped with &#34;8-SERIES&#34; and these are stamped with &#34;Double-Precision&#34;.]
  432. My razor is an 8894 XL but others using the HQ8 cutters are similar. There is no reason not to replace the cutters when the razor advises to do so. It only takes about 5 minutes and most of that time is getting the package open. :) When installing the cutters, lift them one at a time from the package and be careful to keep the 2 parts of each cutter together as they are matched. To reset the \\"replace advisor indicator\\", press and hold down the power button until the razor beeps. (About 4 seconds) Then you're good to go. A new razor is over $200. Amazon's price with free shipping is impossible to beat!
  433. The shaving heads were a perfect fit and they did what my old worn out heads could not do: give me a close shave. I made the correct choice replacing my shaver heads instead of purchasing a new electric shaver.

  481. I replace the heads on my shaver every year or so to keep them sharp. Amazon has a pretty decent price on the heads. Usually if I see them in stores they are around $30 to $35 for a set. I see no reason to buy a new shaver if heads are all I need. I bought my shaver in 2004 or 2005 and it was $100 at the time for the model with NiMH batteries. At the time, lesser models came with NiCad batteries and held less charge and the higher model had lithium batteries and held more charge. These heads keep my shaver going strong even after 6 or 7 years. I get a decent shave without the mess of a wet shave with razor so I'm content. Only problem I've had with my shaver are the batteries. For the past year or so I noticed the run time on my shaver was decreasing. It cost me about $8 to get two AA-sized NiMH batteries with solder tabs and about an hour to replace them. My shaver is good for another 6 years unless something else breaks. No reason to buy a new shaver if all it needs is batteries and heads to keep it going. At $25/year I think this is less than I'd spend on blades. Please note that not all shavers will use the same batteries; you'll need to verify the quantity and size before proceeding with the replacement. Replacement also involves cutting leads and soldering the batteries in place; it does require a bit of soldering knowledge.
  482. Changing out the blades each years is a must to keep the razor working fine. I've done this for years now. Some will say it is an unnecessary expense but for me it's a must.

  753. I have the Norelco 8825XL and this is my 3rd replacement set of head that I have purchased from Amazon over the past 8 years. Since it really feels like a new shaver again, it is like buying your current shaver for just 21 bucks.<br /><br />Before buying yet another set of replacement heads, I took a look at all the current shavers, reading all the reviews, figuring that after 8 years, perhaps it was not worth it to spend any more money on my old shaver.<br /><br />In the end, I decided that I'd rather have an 8825XL over any of the current 2012 crop. They are all short in at least one of these areas that my shaver does fairly well with:<br /><br />It is a wet/dry shaver that travels well. There is no bulky and fragile support stand to lug around for those 3 week+ trips.<br /><br />It can be used plugged in when the battery finally fails or stops before I am done shaving.<br /><br />It is completely reliable. Many of the current Lithium battery shavers seem to be dying within 2 years. There is no way to use them without the battery being charged and it appears that the chargers are killing the batteries prematurely. This was never a problem with the old battery technology (tho I have always COMPLETELY drained my batteries before re-charging.. so far I am nearly 3,000 shaves and 8 years with the original batteries).<br /><br />It may not do as well as a razor, but none of the current crop do any better. The $300 Norelco 1280X/42 SensoTouch seems to come close, but they are charging an arm and a leg for the attempt to get the battery technology working almost as well as the older-and-cheaper NiCad technology.<br /><br />I can replace the batteries when they finally do die.<br /><br />In the end, I figured that until someone decides to make a shaver that is clearly better than the one I have now, why not just keep getting these replacement heads every other year until the motor dies, which could easily be 50 years from now.

  1005. I got this set of replacement shaving / cutting heads recently, for my Phillips AquaTouch AT890 razor. The razor gives a nice shave, and it includes a &#34;replacement indicator&#34; which lights up when the cutting heads need to be replaced. Although the packaging says that the blades should be replace once a year the indicator only lit up after about 18 months, so I got extended use out of them. The blades are relatively easy to replace. I found the instructions on the package to be less clear than they could have been, but it didn't take long to figure out - an assembly that holds the blades needs to be removed from the razor; small locking screws that hold the blades in place need to be removed; then the blades themselves need to be removed from the assembly. The new blades need to be inserted into the assembly; new locking screws installed; and then the assembly placed back into the razor. The replacement only needs to take a couple of minutes once you figure it out. Shaving / cutting blades do need to be replaced, and Phillips has developed a relatively easy and effective replacement routine.
  1006. My Norelco is over a year old these replacement heads gave it a new go , shaves like new again for a decent price
  1007. Not much to say, it is a replacement part. Does what is expected. Seems like they changed them from the original.

  1073. I have had my AT880 for one year. I was going to replace the HQ8 heads but before doing so I decided to clean the heads. Remember to keep the cutters and covers as matched pairs. I cleaned out each part where the hair had gotten caught and created drag on the blades. Also cleaned around the cover. The razor now cuts almost like new. I may hold off replacing the heads. Soap and water plus a toothbrush cleaned everything. In order to keep the matched heads, I marked each set with dots, 1,2,or 3. When cleaning , the heads sometime fall into the sink and would be impossible to match without my markings.
  1074. Wow what a difference! I should have bought this six months ago. My face says thanks every day. I think I will order a set for my razor downstate.

  1101. The replacement heads come as three unmounted cutter assemblies, rather than as a single assembled head as shown in the description. Replacement was not difficult, providing you can see and understand the micro sized instruction drawings on the package. No other guidance is provided. It took some playing around to get the three loose subassemblies in posiition, then replace the holder (spider), assuring the three points of engagement are made. A separate, larger instruction sheet would have been useful. Shaver works fine.

  1232. Arrived on time and as advertised.
  1233. What can you say about a perfect product......
  1234. My Norelco model has an internal system to let you know when to clean it, recharge it, or replace the heads based on actual usage. Very civilized. These replacements are very easy to install and do a fine job of restoring a close shave. The blades and heads are matched sets and the blades are razor sharp (duh), so you need to be cautious not to let the head sets come apart, including when you open the packaging. Each goes in only one way, so take note of where the flat spot on the side of each head is oriented as you remove each old head and match it as you put in the new. I removed the heads and replaced each before moving to the next position, just to make that orientation easier. This is much easier if you remove the entire head assembly from the body of the shaver first.
  1235. Fitted my husbands needs perfectly.
  1236. Changed the shaver blades in my Norelco Shaver but didn't really notice any difference in the shave. Not sure if it was necessary.
  1237. Fit my husband's razor perfectly! He's now back to that close shave that is out of style but still his favorite!
  1238. Be careful to buying this item, and make sure it is what you are really looking for. This is not Replacement Heads ( what is suggest picture on it ) , but only some parts of the head and in my opinion better to buy new whole razor.

  1253. worked for me! Still using them
  1254. The actual process of changing the heads was easier than I expected. I am not especially mechanical and wondered at first why I could not buy the entire head assembly and just pop it on. There was a video of the head change I watched about 4 times. You twist the clover leaf looking thing and lift the assembly that includes the three little rings that holds the heads on. Then you can dump out the heads and old cutters. The instructions say &#34;Make sure that the projections of the shaving heads fit exactly into the recesses.&#34; This is the slightly tricky part. Little tabs on the sides of the heads have to fit in little spaces to seat properly. I am not sure I actually saw how those go together but if you have reasonably good eyes and are patient you can see when it is right (it will go together wrong). I'd recommend just putting in the heads and when you get those seated properly you can just drop in the cutters.<br />And no more pull when I shave. Yay.
  1255. I am using the shaver and seems to be ok. I did have trouble getting the blades in and the shaver is making strange sounds.
  1256. prompt service ,right product
  1257. These are poor quality. I ended up just throwing them away and buying a new razor.

I found online that the rash was really avoidable if I exfoliated my skin a couple of times a week to get rid of dead skin and bacteria, and exfoliating also gives you a much better shave. I figured it was worth a try, so I ordered this[[ASIN:B00U1J83SQ TreeActiv Anti Acne & Rosacea Treatment Sulfur Mask Plus Rhassoul, Bentonite Clay Mask with Witch Hazel & Aloe Vera - Refreshing Lemon Scent (1 Jar) (4 Oz)]] online, and whoa--it worked really well. It felt a little funny at first to use such a thick cream on my face, but it really helped make my shave so much smoother and I also was able to get rid of some of the painful razor bumps that I get every so often on my face. I definitely recommend changing your blades more often than 4 years in between, and just in general it helps to exfoliate your face a few times a week for super smooth shaves that you will have to do less of. Also, I use [[ASIN:B00LFT0CEO TreeActiv+ Tea Tree Oil Acne Solution for Advanced Acne Treatment - All Natural Acne Spot Treatment - Blemishes Gone or Your Money Back!   1662. Like most users, after using an electric razor month after month, you just forget how old the blades really are. Sure they get rid of the stubble and ok, it may take a little longer with the passing months, but gee didn't I just get new blades less than a year ago? Usually it's more like 2 years as in my case. New head makes the shave lots easier and takes less time. Worth the $20+. As for the guy that said his shave was worse with the new heads, perhaps he didn't seat them properly. The housing screen surrounding each rotary blade must seat fully. There 2 tiny angles that fit precisely into the housing. Otherwise the blades can't do their job properly. I had that issue several years ago with a previous model although this one is engineered similarly. Once I discover the issue, it hasn't happened again. Do it with good lighting and not first thing in the morning when your eyes haven't adjusted to the world. Great razor. My only caveat should you need a new razor and not just replacement heads, go with the model that is made in The Nederlands. Avoid the Chinese, Mexican, etc models. They cost a little more but are worth it for durability and longevity IMVHO.
  1663. I have yet to find an electric razor that can provide as close a shave as the disposable razors in the same amount of time. I actually have not used these as I have boxed up the razor and put it on the shelf and returned to the good ole disposable razors. I get a much closer shave in a lot less time.
  1664. I got a clean shave for the first four or five months, then the shaver started to leave stubble and individual whiskers more frequently as the days went by. I do not have a heavy beard and only shave once a day. Was hoping to get closer to a year before having to replace the blades.
  1665. If your razor is over 2 years old, I highly recommend replacing the blades to make it work like new again.

  1747. Replacing the originals as recommended after almost exactly one year, these made a huge improvement in the quality and feel of my shave. One thing that should be noted: I expected to receive a single triangular frame containing the three heads as the illustration implies. What you actually get is the three circular shaving heads as separate items that must be installed individually in the shaver. It's not difficult to do but takes a little more finger dexterity than I expected. Each circular head has little tabs on its edge so that it can only be installed in one orientation. It can't be done wrong, but you have to watch what you're doing to do it right. The improvement in shaving performance was tremendous - almost beyond the performance of the brand new shaver.
  1748. Hard to replace, no proper instruction given

It never shaves close enough-so I had changed to shaving with a hand triple edge razor. As soon as the replacement head arrived, and was (easily) replaced in under 5 minutes. WOW!! UNBELIEVABLE!! Easy all the way around.

  1907. I've been a fan of Norelco razors and used them for about 15 years. I've never had problems with them and frankly the main reason for not using the same razor for the whole time is that I have wanted the \\"upgrades\\" available in newer razors after a few years either more battery life or newer shaving head, such as the Spectra which is superior to the older styles. Their replacement heads are very easy to change and the new heads make a significant difference in closeness. I highly recommend that you replace the heads on an annual basis for best shaving quality/closeness and don't take a chance with replacement heads that are not Norelco OEM products.
  1908. Quick service -- two days! Just like a new razer! <br />THANKS!
  1909. I had the original heads on my Norelco for a couple years and finally had enough and bought these, they advise to replace yearly and I agree with that as 2 years was too long. Love these new, shaver feels like new again with smooth cuts. Quick shipping on this and worth it.
  1910. For years my husband used a regular razor and shaving cream, but constantly had break-up/ingrown hair problems. He HATED shaving. I agree with another comment - he starts to break-out when they dull, but new blades correct the problem. I thank God for this razor. He'll finally shave at least every other day now. (It used to be a battle to do it 1-2 times a week with the way he bled from shaving.)
  1911. When you want something good for a low price, do not click on the 1st picture that pops up. Even when Amazon has it for sale. This item had a range for price to double what I paid for it on the Amazon site. I got this item at 1/2 price the retail with free 2day shipping thru Amazon Prime.
  1912. Replacement blades are a must. The razor will remind you about once a year which is fine in most cases. But, if you have a heavy beard or shave more than once a day, as I do, then you should replace the blades every 8 months or so. The reminder on the razor is only a suggestion, not a command. After all, it does not know when the blades get dull. So, I simply ignore the reminder and replace the blades when I feel it is necessary.<br /><br />One thing you must do is use the new blades for several days until they settle in and adjust to your skin. Until then you may have a little irritation. Another problem I have solved is the hair on my neck. I use to think the harder I press the razor, the better it would get those stray hairs. But, all I got was a rash. I discovered that if I simply use a very light touch and not press hard then it got those hairs much better and with no redness.<br /><br />Replace your blades at least once a year and your face with thank you.
  1913. The subject razor heads arrived on schedule and are performing satisfactorily. I more or less, have a new razor for much less than the actual price of a new one.
  1914. The product was exactly what I expected, at a lower price than the manufacturer's web site.
  1915. I have had Norelco razors my entire adult life, and the only way I've found to truly rejuvenate them, other than replacing the batteries, is to periodically replace the heads....a little spendy, but if you use this every day for 2 years, they pay for themselves with renewed comfort.
  1916. I had delayed replacing the heads because I thought this was just a money-maker for the company and it didn't make any difference. I was surprised that it did make a noticeable improvement in the performance of my shaver.
  1917. After shaving exclusively with my Norelco for nearly eight months I started to notice occasional whisker plucks (ouch!) and I wasn't getting the close shave I was becoming acustomed to. I decided to replace the shaving heads, regardless of Norelco's annual replacement recommendation, to see what difference it would make. The difference was stunning. I again get a close, clean shave without any plucks. For all practical purposes I have a new razor.<br /><br />I'm posting this review just to emphasize that Norelco's annual replacement recommendation of your shaving heads is just that... only a recommendation and is perhaps a little bit optimistic. I'd say to replace the heads when you start to feel that you are not getting the quality shave that you expect and you'll probably feel like you got a new razor.

I always felt that the HQ8 shaver worked faster than the more expensive HQ9 shaver. Even though the HQ9 had more rings, the blades were tiny and I always finished shaving faster when I used the HQ8.<br /><br />I ordered new HQ8 heads for both shavers (they are interchangable). When replacing the blades, I realized that, although they look identical from the top, the new heads have about 50% fewer blades than the original heads did. After replacing the heads, both shavers are as slow as the old HQ9 shaver. I am disappointed. I suspect Philips Norelco cheapened the HQ8 percicely because they didn't want their cheaper shavers working better than their more expensive products.

  1981. These heads are a exact drip-in replacement as advertised for my model.<br />The blades come in the head-unit dry... so without mixing the blades 1,2,3, (my numbering- they actually look alike), because they are run-in to fit their own sockets, (don't mix them up later when spring-cleaning), I removed the blades carefully to examine them, and after applying a very light coat of 4-In-1 sewing machine oil to each blade-unit, I reinserted the 3 blades and ran the razor. The razor hummed along like new!<br /><br />In use a few time now, I feel the blades (or metal/tempering), are not exactly the same quality or edge sharpening grind, as my original &#34;old&#34; blades from Norelco when new. The shave is not as close and clean as expected, (same as the throw-away razors/blades, also from major old-time brand companies...outsource from China?). But overall, this was a good purchase. It quickly &#34;refurbished&#34; an older razor at half the cost of a new one.<br />A good buy!

  2058. After using these replacement blades for several days, getting them as a Christmas gift, I came here truly expecting a lot of negative reviews. But that's not the case. So I'm wondering...<br /><br />I have used Norelco shavers most of my adult life (I'm 62). I have a light beard so they have always worked well, though the cheaper models don't shave as closely or don't have the adjustments that the more expensive (and much too expensive) shavers have.<br /><br />Before the internet, I used to take my shavers to a local repair shop to have the worn out battery replaced. I'd also have the rotary blades replaced too. It was always like getting a brand new shaver for a quarter of the cost of a new one. That was before they started manufacturing many of the models in China. But now that we can order the blades online, I put them on my Amazon Christmas list and got them a week ago. This is my first time getting them online and I have to say I'm somewhat disappointed.<br /><br />I have the model 7810 XL shaver and on the back of the shaver it lists the HQ8 as the replacement blades. And even though the above blade chart's page alignment is messed up, the description above says that the HQ8 blades are for the 7800 series shavers. Good so far. Well I just put them in the shaver two days ago and am pretty disappointed in the shave I'm getting. I'm having to run the shaver over the same area two to three times more often and longer than with the old worn out blades I had. I'm guessing this shouldn't be the case. Of course, over the years things change and quality goes down. I hope this is not the case with these blades.<br /><br />Now back in the day, we used to get &#34;self-sharpening&#34; blades. That's kind of a scary thought since we are putting these cutters on our faces but they do rub against the metal combs and I assumed that over a period of time they keep sharp and maybe even become sharper. I don't know if this is the case but maybe I just got a set of bad ones. Yet, all three wouldn't be bad would they?<br /><br />So that's my experience right out of the box. I'll keep using them and see what transpires and update the review if things improve! I hope your experience is a more positive one.   2060. For what it's worth I think Norelco really messed up when they went to this style of head with the holes and slots instead of just the slots. I have an old beater Norelco that has the old style heads and it shaves twice as fast if not faster and gives a much closer shave. With these new ones you pretty much rub the whiskers off instead of cutting them and if you don't look close it leaves stray whiskers here and there. Sure the old style did pull on the longer ones but at least it cut them off. I thought these would help and they did some, maybe it takes 5 seconds less time now. My beard is fairly soft so I suppose that could be part of it but the old style worked just fine.

  2074. I have been an extremely satisfied customer annually purchasing this specific model of Norelco replacement heads here on Amazon since 2011. It's just the thing that my Norelco 7810XL and 7130XL shavers need to once again be restored to like new condition.<br /><br />And you really do notice the difference in the closeness of the shave when first replacing approximately one-year-old heads with these new razor-sharp beauties.<br /><br />Why waste your money frequently purchasing an expensive, brand new electric shaver when all that you really need to do in most cases is replace the shaving heads/blades to notice a dramatic difference?<br /><br />After all, where the blades meet your skin is where the action is. Full-featured (many superfluous or gimmicky) electric shavers with fancy housings costing $200.00 to $300.00 rarely provide a better shave and certainly not one that is sufficiently better to warrant the significantly higher expense of upgrading your entire electric shaver every few years.<br /><br />These precision HQ8 heads are very simple to replace/install on the pertinent Norelco models that use them. About the only thing that needs a little bit of extra attention is ensuring that the protruding edge/notch on each of the three replacement heads fits properly into the head holder. Either take a closer look at the old heads to see how they are seated before removing them, or slowly and carefully rotate the new heads when installing them and they will eventually just drop into place when everything is properly aligned.<br /><br />If you purchase these HQ8 dual precision replacement heads through the Amazon Subscribe and Save program and get 15% off when ordering 5 or more subscription items at one time like I do, you will spend just about $20.00 for one set of these replacement heads - a very reasonable price indeed for a what is essentially a brand new electric shaver.<br /><br />This hermit - and especially his whiskers - recommends this item without any reservations.servations.

My rating is based more on &#34;room for improvement&#34; in the listing than the product.<br /><br />I may have missed it, but for those that haven't previously bought replacement &#34;heads&#34; for this type of razor, &#34;head&#34; means the package includes both &#34;cutters&#34; (the part that does the cutting, that isn't externally visible) and &#34;combs&#34; (the part you see while looking at it).<br /><br />Also, while the manufacturer recommends annual replacement, the &#34;subscribe and save&#34; option has 1-6 months only, with 4 months as &#34;most common&#34;, which makes that seem like a generic option and not based on the expected use of the product itself. I don't shave &#34;every day without fail&#34;, so these tend to last longer than average for me anyway. It would be helpful if the options were perhaps 6, 9, 12, 15, 18 months.

  2192. Replacing the blades [heads] every 6 - 12 months is still cheaper than purchasing a new Norelco razor. I've not noticed any irritation after installing new heads, just a better shave with less effort. Keep your old razor and replace the heads! You can't go wrong! Amazon's price for these HQ 8 Spectra replacements was the lowest I could find on the Internet. Shipped very fast!<br />Thes factory-authorized replacement cutters correct these problems. They are easily installed, but you must be careful to line up the stationary part wings with the slots in the shaver head designed for them or the cutters will not allow you to close the head properly. It is a simple positioning step.<br />Be very careful not to separate the movable cutters from their stationary housing, as they are carefully ground together for a perfect fit - and a good clean cut.<br /><br />I have tried the newer norelcos that have different screen designs and have not gotten a closer shave than with this model. The blades stay sharp for over a year! It is rare to find a product that works exactly as it is meant to and exceeds your expectations for performance and longevity. That is exactly what these norelco blades and razors do for me. I highly recommend and won't change from this razor set.

  2206. Buyer be aware. Like several others, I was enticed by the excellent price. While the box might say HQ8 the head covers did not fit into my Norelco razor that was also bought (twice) from Amazon. Something is wrong! I've subsequently found other reviewers with the same complaint. I tried for nearly an hour to twist and turn these new head covers to fit into the three holes from the cutting blades. THEY DID NOT FIT AND COULD NOT BE MADE TO FIT. I followed the solution of others, removed the the cutting blades from their covers and used the old head cover with the new blades inserted into them. I have no idea if these are fake copies of Norelco product, or if a new factory did not follow specs. But \\"Something is rotten in Denmark\\", albeit this is a supposed reputable company in the Netherlands. I now question my second purchase of the original Norelco shaver that I bought as a gift for my new grandson-in-law. This flaw in replacements parts will seriously impact my purchase of another Norelco product.....frustration!!! The advertised picture shows a total new razor top containing the blades, but what you receive are three blades with their head covers sealed in a plastic box. Surprised! Yes. Disappointed and frustrated they do not fit. A label HQ8 means nothing if they are not the real thing.

  2554. These replacement heads make a Norelco shaver like new again. They are well made and (for me) last more than the one year Norelco suggests for replacement.<br /><br />Aside from the blades themselves, they also replace the head, a grate above the blades. This is important because the grate can bend if you just throw the shaver in your luggage without its protective cover.<br /><br />For the same reason, you should be careful when you open the packaging. The inside plastic container is a little hard to open, and when I did, the heads fell to the floor and scattered. I don't know for sure, but I suspect that that is the reason they did not work well - so I got a replacement, and was more careful.<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE<br /><br />Four stars, which on Amazon means \\"I like it\\". They do what they should do, and nothing to complain about (except maybe the packaging).
